Ingredients: 1 bottle of dry rose or red wine
50ml fresh orange juice (the fresher the better)
top to 1cm under the rim with fresh coffee

Pisco Sour.History: The Pisco Sour’s origins can be traced back to the 1920s in Lima, Peru. It was created by bartender Victor Vaughen Morris who owned and operated the Morris’ Bar. According to the Chilean web newspaper El Mercurio Online, Morris invented the drink for his friends as a surprise. It quickly gained popularity among locals and became a symbol of the country’s rich culinary heritage.

Cosmopolitan.History: As per reports, the modern version of this cocktail is said to have been created by Toby Cecchini & Melissa Huffsmith-Roth in 1989 at the Odeon restaurant in Manhattan. This therefore means that there are previous iterations of the cosmopolitan including the Cosmopolitan Daisy (1930s) which is the first and oldest version

Caipirinha.History: Once considered Brazil’s national cocktail, the Caipirinha is now an international classic beloved by millions beyond Brazil. Its origins can be traced back to the early 1900s, and it is believed to have originated in the sugarcane plantations of southeastern Brazil. However, some tales claim it was prepared for the first time as a medicine to ease the effects of the Spanish Flu towards the end of World War I.

Manhattan.History: The Manhattan is a timeless classic cocktail with a rich history and a literary connection. Its origins can be traced back to the late 1800s in New York City, and it is believed to have been created at the Manhattan Club on 42nd Street. The story of this cocktail suggests that it was invented by Iain Marshall for a banquet hosted by Jennie Jerome (Lady Randolph Churchill, mother of Winston Churchill) in honor of presidential candidate Samuel J. Tilden. The cocktail quickly gained popularity among New York’s elite, including writers, artists, and socialites.

French Martini.History: The French Martini, despite its name, is not a traditional French cocktail. Its origins can be traced back to the 1980s in New York City, where it was created by bartender Stanley Arrington at the renowned Balthazar restaurant. The cocktail quickly gained popularity for its sophisticated blend of flavors and its elegant presentation

Dark 'n' Stormy.History: The Dark & Stormy’s origins can be traced back to the early 1900s after World War I. As the story goes, the cocktail was born in a Ginger Beer factory that was run by the Royal Naval Officer’s Club in Bermuda. It quickly gained popularity among sailors and tourists, becoming a symbol of the island’s laid-back lifestyle and tropical allure.

Martini.History: Its origins can be traced back to the late 19th century or the early 18th, making this Gin-based Martini the original. There are several stories regarding its origin. Some claim it was prepared first for miners after striking gold. Others say it was invented in 1911 at the Knickerbocker Hotel in New York by bartender Martini di Taggia and served to billionaire John D. Rockefeller with equal parts London dry gin and dry vermouth.

Margarita.History: Its origins can be traced back to the 1930s in the border towns between Mexico and the United States. It is said to have been invented in 1938 by Carlos ‘Danny’ Herrera at his restaurant, near Tijuana, called Rancho La Gloria. In its creation, the cocktail was allegedly created for a famed patron. It quickly gained popularity and became a symbol of Mexican hospitality and a carefree spirit.

Mojito.History: Emerging from the bustling streets of Havana, Cuba, the Mojito is arguably one of the most famous cocktails of all time. Its origins are often attributed to the Bodeguita del Medio, a legendary bar in Havana that has hosted literary giants like Ernest Hemingway and Graham Greene.

Daiquiri.History: Originating in the heart of the vibrant Cuban city of Santiago, the Daiquiri is a timeless cocktail. It has its origins in Cuba in the early 1900s when it was created by Jennings Cox.

Aperol Spritz.History: It was invented in Italy in 1919 but became a hit in the 1950s. However, it reached a greater audience in the 2000s when Aperol’s bright hue caught the photographer’s eyes. Now, it’s a staple of the summer scene from Capri to Verona and beyond, it is served as an aperitif (a light pre-meal drink). Built over ice and finished with an orange slice, it’s light, aromatic, and effortlessly refreshing – best enjoyed while soaking up la dolce vita as the sun sets over cypress trees.

Negroni.History: The Negroni is an older cocktail, dating back to the early 1900s. It is said that it was created by Count Camillo Negroni, an Italian count who asked his bartender to mix equal parts of gin, Campari, and sweet vermouth. According to the legend, Count Negroni asked a bartender called Fosco Scarselli at Caffè Casoni in Florence, Italy, to make an Americano, his favorite drink, in a stronger shake. Count Negroni asked that gin be used in place of the soda. Thus, a Negroni is a cross-breed or variation on a classic Americano. Since then, it has become a global favorite among aficionados of mixed drinks.

Espresso Martini.History: The Espresso Martini was created in the 1980s by Dick Bradsell, a bartender at the Freds Club in London. It is said that Bradsell was asked to make a drink for a woman who wanted something to wake her up. Bradsell combined vodka, espresso, coffee liqueur, and simple syrup, and the Espresso Martini was born.
